summary: Email from the Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) to an unspecified recipient, providing information on OIG investigations into falsification of inmate logs at BOP facilities, including cases at Butner, Leavenworth, and Petersburg. The email references the OIG's support for a deferred prosecution decision by a U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO) and requests a statement of facts regarding log falsification and direction from superiors. It also includes BOP data on inmate deaths at New York and Brooklyn facilities.

persons.name: Deputy Assistant Inspector General for Investigations
persons.context: The official from the DOJ Office of the Inspector General who is providing information on OIG investigations into falsified logs at BOP facilities and supporting a deferred prosecution decision.

events.title: OIG Investigations into Falsified Logs at BOP Facilities
events.description: The OIG has multiple open cases regarding falsification of logs at various BOP institutions, including inmate deaths at Butner, Leavenworth, and Petersburg, resulting in guilty pleas, probation, fines, administrative charges, and proposed removals.

events.title: Deferred Prosecution Decision by USAO
events.description: The OIG supports the decision of the U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO) regarding a deferred prosecution and requests a statement of facts related to falsification of logs and information on direction from superiors.

keyFacts: The DOJ OIG has multiple open cases regarding falsification of inmate logs at BOP facilities, including cases linked to inmate suicides and homicides.

In cases closed since January 1, 2019, sustained charges of log falsification resulted in disciplinary actions including suspensions (50), terminations (3), and resignations/retirements prior to discipline (6).
The OIG supports a deferred prosecution decision by a U.S. Attorney's Office and seeks a statement of facts regarding log falsification and any direction from superiors.
BOP data on inmate deaths at New York and Brooklyn facilities is included, but the BOP system cannot reliably associate inmate deaths with employee discipline.
The email references U.S. Code 5 USC ยง3322 regarding the retention of investigations in an employee's permanent personnel file.
